For the first time in over 20 years, the spirit of Star Trek has been recaptured and beautifully rendered in this ambitious, riveting, unutterably superb, watertight thriller about a cosmic conspiracy to destroy that oh-so-wonderful secular paradise epitomised and encapsulated by the Federation. It stands out not just against the backdrop of the Star Trek canon, but perhaps all of television history.
Classic science fiction - lovin it

I think desperation has set in for the fanbase. The show is definitely not perfect or a 'must see', it's not even particularly good. It's watchable and has some fun and exciting drama. If this was the first season and not the finale, it would be fine, but it's too little WAAAYY too late. 

Pros: all the main characters from TNG are back and act like the aged version of themselves with new arcs and growth to their characters. Visual production is cinematic and great. The story is good and keeps you invested and guessing at the season long mystery. Some of the new characters are also great with great preformances.
 
Cons: There is still A LOT of filler, especially in the middle episodes 4-6, but every episode moves the plot along. Some of the characters (Ravi) are still written poorly and their performances are awful. The story's conclusion is just the lamest, eye-rolling, forced ending since TNG's 'Conspiracy' (just really dumb and self indulgent sci-fi action, Seven's action scenes probably being the worst thing I've seen in a Star Trek series, but I've also avoided most of new-Trek). There's a lot of coincidence and forced plots to wrap up episodes that weren't going anywhere, way too many for a show this short. 

Conclusion: If you're a really big fan of TNG it's worth a watch. I couldn't really recommend it to casual fans of Star Trek or sci-fi in general unless they already had a Paramount+ subscription or were just really desperate for something new to watch that was written well enough and exciting throughout. I doubt I'll ever revisit it, and I'll probably forget I ever watched it within the year.

yeah....not.

As a lifelong Star Trek TNG fan, I absolutely adored this series. So many beautifully nostalgic moments but mixed in with a fresh and exciting storyline. You can see the chemistry the cast still have after so many years and it is one of the finest bits of television I have ever seen. I know some people have criticised but if you watched the original next gen series, you have to watch this!

Season 3 was great and far preferable to the ponderous muddles that were Seasons 1 and 2. It brought back together the old gang in a presumably final reunion tour, which was a very smart move.

There were a couple of drawbacks to the season, though. First, it had one of the most annoying villains I've ever seen on tv or in the movies. Second, for the most part it didn't live up to the way in which the original Next Generation used futuristic, sce-fi settings to probe current issues.

Nonetheless, Season 3 was a thoroughly enjoyable romp that occasionally poked fond fun at its original Next Generation characters and characteristics, while remaining true to the spirit of that enterprise. And it showed how good an ensemble cast can be, as the actors seemed to enjoy appearing with and playing off each other one last time.

Third Season is a great farewell to the belowed Next Generation show. It provides closure and a bit of healing after the truly horrible seasons 1 and 2. Every star trek fan should skip anything after 2009 and go straight to this. I hope Terry Matalas will do a new show with the Enterprise G crew.

An excellent end to the series and homage to all the previous iterations of Star Trek. The first two seasons were reasonably good despite a few bad plot choices. The choice of using music from the original series movies right up to Voyager and Deep Space 9 themes was the perfect way to link the various characters and strands of the story together while creating a healthy dose of Trek nostalgia.

"Star Trek: Picard" - Season Three Review

By the third season, "Star Trek: Picard" is deep into the nostalgia realm, ticking boxes that fans have long been clamoring for. And while this might sound like a redeeming feature, it's actually a double-edged sword. On one hand, it finally feels like the show is giving fans what they've desired, but on the other, it underscores a three-year journey of missed opportunities. Even in its best moments, the series lacks the heartfelt, character-driven narratives that have made Star Trek an enduring phenomenon. The glaring mismatch between what "Picard" could be and what it is, seems to point directly at Alex Kurtzman. And with shows like "The Orville" by Seth MacFarlane capturing more of the Trek spirit, even with its off-kilter humor, one can't help but wonder if a change in leadership wouldn't set "Picard" on a better course.
Disappointed we may never see quite the ensemble again.

More Star Trek is better as studios hide the series behind paywalls, instead of broadcasting it for free, and as the fanbase ages out.

Season 3 was too much of a return to TNG, too many glances back at TNG for nostalgia, and too much emotional build up over characters I had little interest or investment in. And even amongst the primary characters some of the additional story came across as forced opportunities to emote for connection to the viewer. I found some of the character's actions and decisions inconsistent such as sacrificing redshirts but going out of the way with extended dialogue and action to save new characters I'm supposed to connect to but have little history to. 

Some legacy character development was disappointing  and the resurrection of others reminded me of how heroes and characters in comic books and prior Star Trek series were handled. To me that cheapened my emotional connection to the first closures, stories, and series and distances me from the series and new productions as nothing past is really permanent; just re-boot the old story for your new story and new audience. Which makes me decide, why should I even invest emotionally. To me it comes across as manipulation (emotional) for the sake of continuity and ratings and that there are no consequences. 

For me, the most emotional moment was hearing Majel Barrett's voice. 

If I see the TNG crew in the future, I'll look forward to very brief appearances that drive a new story forward instead of looking back and sitting in nostalgia.

This is the worst installment of any of the Star Trek series. I enjoyed the first two seasons of this series, but Season 3 was a gigantic miss. Everything was wrong with Season 3. The characters were wildly different than they were in SNG and their interactions were often entirely unrealistic. Geordi was a complete wimp. Riker was largely a weakling who shockingly and publicly disrespected Picard in early episodes. Riker's relationship with Troi was always annoying, He must have said Emsadi like 20 times. Worf was a caricature. The Data return--again--was unrealistic and Data-Lore duality really forced. I can't maker heads or tails of Dr. Crusher's back story. And I thought the Picard's-son narrative was really forced. I liked the main villain and Seven of Nine though. The fall of Star Fleet ran entirely counter to the 50+ year canon. And the ultimate resolution of the Dominion was far far too easily accomplished. The whole series felt phoned in and seemed as if it was written by the D team.
I'll take a Nostalgia trip any day of the week that's half as good as this season. I don't know how they saved it from the pits of Season 2, but they did it.

My God, THIS IS STAR TREK, please, more and hopefully beyond with the same vigor, and same love for what makes Star Trek, Star Trek.

Love this season so much

Don't get me wrong, season 1 and 2 had their moments, but holy smokes season 3 blows them both away. I only got into Trek about four or five years ago, but since finishing the original various series and movies, I've been wanting a TNG reunion like this. It's like Paramount gifted Trekkies everything they thought we wanted, and I love that. When a fandom is crying out with similar ideas of what they like and want to see, listen. That's what it seems like Paramount did with this, SNWs, and Lower Decks. So flippin good. It's shocking to me how emotional I got during this season. It's like when everyone gets introduced I start balling. When Data inevitably does his thing and saves the ship, I couldn't stop crying. Data helped me get over a lifelong fear and chronic nightmares of terminator-like things, so seeing him back in action doing what he does best was amazing. I'll admit I haven't finished the season yet, I have about two more episodes I think, but I just couldn't standby without showing my appreciation to the staff and producers that worked so hard to make this show and season as good as it was, especially season three. 

The ship museum and stealing parts from the ship that crashed into San Francisco Bay in Whale Trek put the biggest smile on my face. I'm almost apprehensive to finish the last few episodes because I don't want it to end 😞 
Hopefully Picard was enjoyable for new fans and old fans alike. When I'm a graceful retired old gal I'll watch this show and reminisce about my good old days and relate to this show in even more ways I can now. 

Live long and prosper 🖖

It was Critical Drinker of all people who got me to reconsider watching this show after the atomic bomb of a failure that was the second season. To be honest, I thought he was trolling us, but I decided to give it a shot and I am so glad I did.

This season was written and directed by people who genuinely cared about the show, were seeking nostalgia while throwing a bit of modern flair into the mix, and left the door open for the Next Next Generation. If they put as much passion into the next show as they did this sendoff, it will be an incredible show.

Gone is the overt political messaging (Star Trek has always been progressive, but it was also hopeful) that sacrificed substance and story, and the heart of this season is a broken family trying to fix their relationship after all these years. Magnificent.

There is soul here where once there was none. If that doesn't tell us that redemption or at least reconciliation is possible, I don't know what can.

Season three unfortunately succombs to small-universe syndrome and overly indulgent nostalgia.
Where the first two seasons boldly went both to the future and the past, season three is happy trying to play the greatest hits. From aping shots from the TOS movies, to the design of the Titan looking like it could have featured in a sequel to TUC.
It jettisons all but one of the original characters introduced in the first season to service a plot that at the same time is overstuffed with characters competing for screentime (Todd Stashwick's Captain Shaw most egregiously gets shoehorned into the plot to retread old ground and be in the way of Seven's character development) and a plot that drags a mystery box out to the final two episodes while we spend the first eight episodes getting the gang back together (partly because of the logistic challenges to get all these actors together) to set up a finale that is tonally deaf and unnecessarily large in scope. 
The season has been billed as a ten-hour movie and that's how it feels like. The show would have been better served had they held the course and this should have been a 2-2.5 hour movie special.
On a positive note, the production design is top notch and the actors' chemistry and love for each other just leaps off the screen and is the saving grace.

I'm not saying the series isn't good - it is, it's the final chapter that I think takes the easy way out. I just felt let down as it devolved into another episode of Next Gen. 'Picard' had been much more complex up to this point with so much interwoven such as his relationship with Laris which, it seems, just gets dropped from the script in the end. I thought Laris was a much more interesting character and made more interesting by Orla Brady.  So it's the old buddies once again, they even find a way to resurrect Data and the fact that the android has aged just gets a sneak by. STNG fans of course will love it and original Trekkies - who knows, they're finicky. Are original fans Trekkies or Trekkers? That always confuses me...

The third season really does act like a 10 hour movie that brings together all you remember and love about the Star Trek TV series in various components possible in this timeline. It never fails to deliver and tends to even surprise. My only complaint is the last stretch of the 10 episode closure to TNG is spent with a wealth of goodbye speeches that seem strangely out of place given the stress of the situations. We know why they did it, and we knew they would leave it open to a new series, but I think they could have tied it up with the same level of thought and grace as the rest of this send off. It doesn't hurt anything, sure, but it goes from being epic, and a masterpiece to just a little sappy right at the point where it shouldn't be. Overall, this is definitely the way to end the TNG run. It serves far better than the previous 2 Picard seasons. Highly recommended. As for the wealth of people complaining that this is nothing new or original, or even going the way of Star Wars - so what? They're not wrong, but so what? TNG ended for all of us a long time ago with Nemesis, and some dismiss that installment. One more adventure, one more recap, and a bit of where are then now. Yes, it is reminiscent, and yes, it feels like every other story people complain about but guess what - the whole history of human kind is exactly that anyhow. We love repeating ourselves. We love pointing fingers and saying this is the same as that, and in doing so, we become the same as everyone and everything else as well. So just watch it like you would an episode of TNG. If you think it smells too much like Star Wars, then just think about how much it also sounds like Batman. When you run out of comparisons, ask yourself if in the moment you liked that you finally got to see Worf get his day. Or that you always knew they would bring Data back from within B4. But did you see it happening this way? Maybe we all can relax on being pissed off for no reason. The only way Picard season 3 could be considered a disservice for me, would be if they made a season 4. I thought "all good things" was a good end for TNG. But honestly, I dislike Q, and I thought this was a far better way to close it off.

Maybe if you've never seen Star Trek: The Next Generation you might enjoy seeing a bunch of supposed Starfleet veterans make mistakes like they're fresh out of the academy. I don't enjoy it, it's not a fitting tribute to the best Star Trek series ever made, it's not true to the characters, and it makes a mockery of Gene Roddenberry's legacy. The comedy falls flat most of the time and the emotional scenes feel hollow. If you like corporate attempts to milk the franchise by providing nothing but shameless fan service then you may enjoy this series but if you want something of substance that upholds the legacy of Gene Roddenberry then forget it.

I've been a die-hard trekkie all my life and TNG was the show I loved the most. This was the best send off for the crew I could have hoped for. TNG was a great series, but not without it's flaws. I was sad that a lot of plot points were never revisited or addressed and annoyed that the last episode 'all good things' left so much unfinished and these weren't fixed in later films. I never thought there would be closure until Picard S3. I had watched S1 and it just wasn't star trek. Picard was more Patrick Stewart than the character of Picard and the universe went against Roddenberry's vision. S2 I totally gave a miss after hearing many people talk about it. I knew it was terrible. I wasn't going to give the series another look until I heard the Red Letter Media guys talk about it and I decided to give it a try. So glad I did! It was written by someone different, someone who actually likes Star Trek, and it shows. The universe and characters were true to themselves.

We finally get a proper end for these characters, to see the female characters actually do something - Gates McFadden actually getting  to do and say stuff of substance! All the characters finishing their arcs in a satisfying way, so much nostalgia and references to the show that made my nerd brain very happy. I'm not so cynical that I cannot enjoy things and enjoy this I did, memberberries and all. This is the first time I have loved a Star Trek show in decades. Been a few ST shows I like or find enjoyable, but not loved. This I will buy to rewatch. To me,  this was not Picard S3, it's TNG: S8. 

It might not have the philosophy that TNG is known for, but it had the action, adventure, and excitement of the films, the nostalgia of the series, with the character depth needed to give it a proper finish.

Only thing I would have liked is if Picard and Crusher actually officially got together. They sort of left that open, but I'm just gonna head-cannon that they did.

Spoiler: I also like the extra scene at the end and look forward to if they do a short series with just Jack and Q, because that would be fun! Let Picard and the crew rest now.

Season 1 & 2 made for enjoyable television, but for some inexplicable reason, season 3 turned into a horrible pastiche. Why do fanboys proudly stand on the peak of mountains and yell "Don't give me anything new or original, just pump reconstituted staleness directly into my veins!!!"

Am I the only person on this earth that would like to see something new? Like Star Wars, Picard is now all about fan service and nothing about art. When you think about the vastness of space, and how the entire universe is your canvas with science fiction, you have to lament how "fans" demand that Terry Matalas makes all future trek and only make what they have already seen. They don't want to be challenged or exposed to anything new, they just want what they have already had, reheated and served on a tinfoil tray.

I can see why Patrick Stewart never wanted this and I commiserate with him. He came back to do something new and has ended up making season 8 of TNG.

This is the best ST season since ST VOY's exit in 2001. So why the 1.5 stars? Because everything else was so cringe from dizzying timelines and alternate realities to the all-encompassing lens flares to killing off episodic mode and getting everything so dark that once iconic sets are now floating projections with no background and least but not last waaay down to using swear words. And with the final two episode of ST P the transition from star trek to Star Wars is complete. If you look at the story's structure it is actually identical with SW episodes 5 and 6 but this time Jack, the son is lured to the dark side and Picard the father is to bring him back with no magic light-sabre duel, but empty words, from a powerless pathetic -once glorious and one of the most celebrated villains in sci-fi film and tv – The Borg Queen aka Emperor Palpatine in the throne room. Then you have the Death Cube and The Enterprise Falcon flying like a, erm, fly through its inner corridors to reach wait for it!... The Core of the super structure where they must destroy it with blast torpedoes. And right when all seems lost Deanna Organa through her Betazodian Jedi skills knows exactly where Jack Skywalker is. R2Data discovers his guts and jumps the ship to lightspeed. They escape the destruction of the super structure just in time and space before getting caught in the blast. The rest is also painful to watch and sad seeing Picard's botched face and voice and Doctor Crusher's super stretched face and skin. But the saddest and most infuriating part is 7o9. For all 3 seasons she was just there as a hot MILF doing nothing at all. Once saving the entire franchise and literally having us all glued to CRT tv-s then DVDs then streaming and rewatching it a million times Seven is just dull as dull can be. The witty replies the perfect body posture the Borg skills and the famous trademark hairdo and futuristic cat suit all gone. She looks and feels not 24th century but definitely 21st. And then the never-ending vomit inducing nostalgia. I understand that it is impossible to write new charismatic characters that can be portrayed by charismatic actors, but I think that is not even Paramount's plan just to have more of the same endlessly. Forgettable and unimpressive absolutely not rewatchable hope still lingers in me that one day somebody will return with the original way of ST the kind Roddenberry visioned.

FINALLY! We have a competent showrunner who also happens to be an honest to god Trek fan! Legacy characters are respected, lore is remembered, emotional scenes are emotional for actual reasons. We need more terry matalas's in hollywood.

"Star Trek: Picard" is a television series on Paramount+. A follow-up series to "Star Trek: The Next Generation" (TNG) and "Star Trek: Nemesis." It centers on retired Starfleet admiral Jean-Luc Picard, beginning about 20 years after Nemesis. 

Patrick Stewart reprises his role as Picard. Season 1 also stars Alison Pill, Isa Briones, Harry Treadaway, Michelle Hurd, Santiago Cabrera, and Evan Evagora. Season 2 adds Jeri Ryan, Orla Brady, Wil Wheaton, Whoopi Goldberg, and Brent Spiner. The 3rd season adds the remaining TNG cast members LeVar Burton, Michael Dorn, Jonathan Frakes, Gates McFadden, and Marina Sirtis.

In a nutshell, each season has its own compelling story. If you are a TNG fan, season 3 is a MUST-WATCH! It is an exemplary sendoff to the TNG storyline. (10/10)

P.S. The series finale (Season 3, Episode 10); continue watching for the post-credits scene!! (Fingers Crossed!!)

The "Picard" series got off to a bit of a slow start, with some uneven pacing and an over-reliance on nostalgia to carry the story forward. However, the final episodes of the series managed to turn things around and deliver a satisfying conclusion that saved the show from being forgettable.

The last few episodes of "Picard" are filled with heart-pumping action, stunning visuals, and poignant character moments. The show's themes of redemption, sacrifice, and legacy are all brought to the forefront, culminating in a finale that left me feeling emotional and satisfied.

The standout performance of Patrick Stewart as Jean-Luc Picard cannot be overstated. He brings a gravitas and nuance to the character that makes him feel both familiar and new. The supporting cast also shines, particularly Isa Briones as Soji and Michelle Hurd as Raffi. The chemistry between the characters is palpable, and their interactions are a joy to watch.

While the series as a whole may have had its flaws, the final episodes of "Picard" more than made up for them. The show's writers managed to tie up loose ends, while also leaving enough room for future storytelling. The final scenes of the series are particularly touching, and serve as a fitting tribute to one of the most beloved characters in the Star Trek universe.

In conclusion, while "Picard" may not have been perfect, the final episodes of the series more than make up for any shortcomings. The show's themes, performances, and production values all come together to deliver a satisfying conclusion that will leave fans of the franchise feeling fulfilled.

As many have said, this is the best Star Trek in 20+ years and the most solid season of Star Trek ever. Clearly from the score, the audience loved it as much as me with just a few dissenters who I think are way off base, particularly two of my favorite YouTube reviewers. Mr. Campea and Angry Joe, go take a look at the audience score of The Mandalorian season 3 and compare it to this. Back to Picard. This truly was an epic series and near perfect. I wish there was more to come and hopefully Terry Matalas will get a chance to helm more Star Trek, especially since Kurtzman Trek has been pretty awful, save some of Strange New Worlds. I have watched all episodes this series at least twice, and the finale 4 times now. If you've been burned by Picard seasons 1 & 2, relax. It's time to come home.

After Star Trek: Nemesis failed to live up to it's potential, I feared that the crew of "The Next Generation" would never get the send-off they deserved. 
  Season 3 of Star Trek: Picard not only patched the hole left by Nemesis, it gave the intrepid crew of the USS Enterprise a 10 episode epic finale that went above and beyond ALL hopes. 

  Cinematic quality from episode 1 to the heart-stopping episode 10, the visuals, music, action, dialogue and performances were perfect. Those who, like me grew up with Picard, Riker, Dr. Crusher, Data, LaForge, Deanna Troi and Mr. Worf will be treated to a real treat.

Star Trek: Picard as a whole was a real treat, and Season 3 was the richest, sweetest icing on the cake. 5/5, *****, 100%, A+++
An amazing series coverd every trekies dream episodes to the end. Did what  Generations movie didnt do for kirk
A truly fitting farewell for the crew of the Enterprise D.

It was a spectacle alright and very TNG in that they teased the audience with character development and traumatic growth but chickened out and pushed the big ol' reset button at the end.  Bringing back Q after his character arc clearly ended is the perfect example of the deeply flawed writing. Instead of leaving Q resolved, it undoes the death of Q and regresses to a Farpoint-esq statement of humanity-on-trial... again.

Likewise the golem was setup to become a fusion of Lore and Data, but just so the audience is not made uncomfortable this is delivered through an absurd fakeout where Lore becomes Data then deletes Lore.  By the rules that the episode established, Lore should have changed as a person after absorbing Data's memories, becoming the blended fusion they teased.  The season is full of this type of internal rule-breaking and pandering to the audience as to avoid any unpleasant or ambiguous outcomes, which is insulting to the viewership.

Throughout the season the writers were clearly afraid of making any intentional changes to the legacy characters, but seem perfectly fine accidentally making Riker forget his daughter, making Picard decide to murder a prisoner with zero reckoning later, and making the Borg a boring revenge-obsessed villain instead of the established and much scarier emotionless assimilators.  Season 3 is a mediocre show masquerading as a great one and relies entirely on the name recognition of its cast to survive.

Don't bother with the first 2 poor seasons, written by the same people who have ruined Star Trek for years. Finally, a fitting tribute to Picards legacy and the Next Generation series. They even managed to redeem previously annoying characters and set up new likeable characters for future series, which is almost unheard of these days. Simply brilliant. THIS is Star Trek!

This season tries to seduce you with simple nostalgic charm that isn't even well done.

It was terrible as usual, it wasn't better than the other seasons, it just cheaply pretended to be Star Trek. Wherever they could, they put the Starfleet symbol on it, almost as inflationary exaggerated as the swastika is shown in ridiculous WWII computer games. If nothing was possible visually at a given moment, then a familiar Star Trek sound was played in the background, regardless of whether it was appropriate or not. The same goes for the music. All the motifs that the franchise used in TV and cinema from 1966 to 2001 were shamelessly used. Of course, the music was used inflationarily, whether it suited or seemed completely overdone. 

Knowing that the characters are legendary to you, they were just portrayed as generally legendary. Each reintroduced with as much exaggerated and misplaced pathos as possible. Sure, even the president is named Chekov. After all, there are only a zillion inhabitants of the Federation, who cares, the President must have something to do with familiar characters.

The plot was just nonsense. The characters were barely recognisable, and I don't mean visually. The decision makers of this show just don't know anything about Star Trek and even worse, they clearly don't like it. This show was so inauthentic and alienating, as if an adult wants to play along with children without having any idea what the cool toy of some hip franchise is all about.

Imagine if this season with this exact plot had taken place as season 8 of TNG. Exactly in the look of TNG and directly after 1994. The fans would have freaked out what this nonsense is about, where only fragments of the Star Trek universe are recognisable and these are highlighted so strikingly, so that it is not noticeable that otherwise the entire plot is simply no longer oriented towards Star Trek.

Many fans are simply so desperate that they cheer because they simply show them the bridge of the Enterprise D again and the Enterprise is back. But that's exactly what every TNG episode, even the worst of them, has offered. These are just the simplest basics. It seems that is enough to satisfy to lot of people. Enough to turn the last rotten tomato to gold these days.

Brilliant. No spoilers here. It's like finding a new episode of TNG. Except there's 10 of them !  It has pretty much everything for any Trek fan (including DSG and Voyager)..  If you're wondering who this is aimed at: Worf falls asleep on a seat at the end of the adventure.. Which is what I also do most evenings these days 😉.

As a fan of the Next Generation as a young boy it was a true pleasure to see the cast back together again in such a fan pleaser of a way. It really set the tone for a handoff of the baton for the next, next generation. I beg Paramount+ for Star Trek : Legacy.
So so good, finally. Really glad they got it right in the end. Fitting end and tribute, absolutely loved it.
Excellent ending for the season

It was average in the end. Started off really well, lots of action and intrigue and it really sucked me in. But it suffered from a few issues. Firstly, they recycled a few things (such as beaming onto the space station and beaming onto the cube) and I wasn't too keen on seeing those plots in the same season. Secondly, it felt like they rushed the last few episodes of the season. We had an interesting plot with the changelings and the main initial baddie, but this plot line literally went out in a whimper rather than a bang, and the connection/history they had with the borg was barely explored. Thirdly, the copypasta fleet *again* - why do the fleet comprise of the SAME ships every time these new series? And why so many? Why do starfleet need so many ships? I suppose for continuity with prior season you had to, but come on! Fourthly, this was like watching an episode of Friends at times. I get that it is a Next Gen reunion, but it was at times like eating a tub full of icing sugar. Fifthly, the cameos/mentions of Voyager and Enterprise (maybe DS9 also) was so weak. Yes, cool, we got to see Archer's old ship (a picture would have been a nice touch) and we saw Tuvok. But that it? Given this is revolving around 7 of 9 a bit, where are the Voyager mentions? Paris? Chakotay? hell even Admiral Janeway didn't appear. Must say but as someone who never watched TNG but got hooked on Voyager/Enterprise I'm in a weird place with these new series. It's either garbage (DISC) or extreme throwbacks like Picard. Hopefully they come out with a Voyager-themed one in the future.

I liked it a lot! I'm generally accepting of fan-service, and, there's no way around it: this is what Season 3 of Star Trek: Picard is all about. And I think they did a great job at that, while still managing to bring about meaningful character development for all the members of the old crew -- really astonishing job at that.

This is, obviously, a series and a season for long-time TNG fans. I'm one of them, so it's tricky to judge this show objectively, since it throughout its run, and this season in particular, plays so much with (in a good way) with our feelings torwards the series and the characters. However, I can confidently say that, for long-time fans of Star Trek, this is not gonna be disappointing. Rather, it's clear how much passion went into this season, even how much it means for the entire cast. It's a love letter for TNG, and a much needed and waited for one at that, and I'm glad to have watched it.

In conclusion: it's a great finale for a (and this is gonna sound controversial) great series. I'm actually one of the rare people who loved Season 1 too (it's true, I really dad), and I feel like Season 3 also did a great job at giving us a peak at the characters we all love's future. It was just marvellous to see the whole crew back together. It's very hard to screw this up, and Paramount managed to do a very enjoyable show around that premise.

As a last side note, I'm glad they made it obvious that a new series around the crew of the Enterprise-G (and particularly Jack Crusher) is a very real possibility. I think that's a great idea and I can't wait to see it if it actually happens. I think that'd make for a great new Star Trek show premise, probably the best one (far ahead of Discovery, Strange New Worlds and Legacy) we've had so far since Star Trek's most recent revival. So let's keep our fingers crossed and hope that they do that. I'm sure all the fans would absolutely love that!

I made an account on RT just for this review.  This was Alex Kurzman's painstaking love letter to Star Trek fans.  As one of those fans, I can't emphasize enough how grateful I am to you all.  This is proof that science fiction, especially Star Trek can still be enthralling and not just capture the imagination, but absolutely lovingly embrace the imagination in a state of joyful wonder.  It also honors the characters that we grew to love and appreciate so much.  I'm going to find it difficult not to vote this as my favorite sustained season of Star Trek ever.  For those of you who don't care for the endless episodes of exposition and character building without the backdrop of action and true science fiction, this is the season you don't want to miss.

Star Trek Picard Season 3 has exceeded all of my expectations. It captures the warmth and hope of Star Trek: TNG, while balancing with the realism we've come to enjoy in the newer Star Trek shows. Lastly, the action is INTENSE. I would argue that this final season is the best final season in all of Star Trek. I'd even go as far as saying that it's the best final season of any Sci-Fi/Fantasy show out there.

I had nothing good to say about seasons one and two, but season three is one of the most magnificent recoveries I have ever seen a show make. This, in this form, is the Picard we wanted. It feels like Star Trek again. Proof that all it takes to be brilliant is a good story, strong writing and a cast and director that understands what Trek is. My pet peeve with the first two seasons was how weak and ineffectual they made Picard. While the writers still write Picard far too philosophical, wordy and indecisive, it's less so this season. Picard was always strong, in charge and a man of few words. I don't think the writers know that Picard, who now has a tendency to self-doubts and likes to blather on at length about his feelings. The old Picard would have cringed at displays like this. Other than that, the cast is solid and fairly true to their characters. They still feel "right". The exception is Worf. The silly pacifist nonsense and jokey stuff doesn't work for me. Amanda Plumber amazes as usual and is easily one of the most effective baddies I've seen on Trek. Great to see her back doing what she does best, being all weird and scary as hell. If there's a weakness here, it's resorting to the Borg as the main villains once again. Yawn. The Changelling connection was inventive though. Captain Liam Shaw is played masterfully by Todd Stashwick. This character along with his ship and crew could easily carry a whole new series on their own. Every single episode of this season has looked and felt like an action-packed movie under the competent and skilled direction of Jonathan Frakes. So much so that Picard season three feels like a whole new show. What a shame this invigorated season is its last. More please!

It is just what we wanted.... It is what Star Trek is about. They captured the essence, the roots, of Star Trek. Seasons 1 and 2 were terrible and boring to me. But for season 3, yes. Finally, we have writers who like and understand the show as much as we do, and understand that the magic comes from the crew. Imagine, what Star Wars could do if they had writers who liked the movies, the characters, and the story....
Season 3 is hands down the best star trek series ever made, I wish it wouldn't end it's that good

The producers/directors/writers did something very simple for this final season.   In the first 2 seasons, it seemed that they were trying very hard to "not be like TNG" and to "avoid too much fan-service".    For the 3rd season, they have completely embraced the TNG roots & provide long time Star Trek fans with plenty of fan service and nods to the older TV series.   This season is easily the best of the 3 by far, and is the best season of any Star Trek series I've seen since Deep Space Nine  - which I consider the best Star Trek series ever.   It was very satisfying to see all the connections to DS9 in this season - perhaps folks who might have "given up" on  DS9 because of the slow first 2 1/2 seasons (before the Dominion arc really kicked into gear)  will go back and give that excellent show another chance.
As close to perfect joy as I've ever experienced.

Excellent, the only bad thing is knowing the season is coming to an end. With no more in sight at this moment.

No more (mostly) with Season 3. Seriously, if you heard all the bad stuff of the first two seasons, don't bother even watching them They will dilute the experience you are getting with the final season. The first two seasons are also not needed story-wise and can be safely discarded.

Let's talk first about the bad stuff in Season 3: They still use a linguistic style here and there that reminds more of the real-world 21st century rather than what they used to in TNG. However, it has been toned down massively in Season 3. Some ship designs are also questionable and seems too experimental to make the backbone of the post-Nemesis Starfleet.

Now to the good stuff, let's continue right with the ship designs here: I love the USS Titan-A, it takes a proven, reliable Starfleet design concept and merges it into the 25th century. While these things are subjective, one will notice that there are WAY more close-up ship shots that can be enjoyed in detail - at last!

Season 3 manages to re-engage with certain open questions that remained from the original TNG show (not gonna write what so as not to spoil) and it is amazing that these little character storylines are being picked up and integrated into the larger story. The larger story itself is engaging and interesting because you want to know for a great part of the series what is going on and certain revelations will entertain you well! 

Fan service and nostalgia are an absolute 10/10. I really, really want to express it but in order not to spoiler I will contain myself and just say: I have waited for this since the 90s!! Set course, engage! Cannot wait for the final episode.
By far the best of all three seasons and the best of Star trek since TNG. perfectly done. So much nostalgia.
Best season so far. Why make such a great season and just stop here?
I forgot the two bad first seasons, but season 3 is excellent and closes the loop on many old storylines from the original series.
A nostalgic ride filled with enough new ideas to make it the best Sci-Fi series in the air.

it is awwful and unwatchable.  These people do not resemble their characters, this is not star trek. the ridiculous constant call backs do not make sense. The writers obviously do not understand or even like star trek.  I am disgusted.

I've seen the great wall of China. I've seen the Pyramids of Egypt.  I've even seen a grown man satisfy a mule!  But I've never seen a more dramatic turn-around of a TV show until now.

Wow!

The first 2 seasons of Picard were bad. Mind-numbingly bad.  Off-the-charts woke bad.

But somehow they turned everything around in season 3.  This show is not perfect, the events don't always seem to tie-together logically.  But the show is well-written, the characters interesting, the plot unfolds at just the right pace, and the action is absolutely thrilling.  And Todd Stashwick as Captain Shaw steals the show in every scene he's in.

Can't recommend this season enough.  Skip the first 2 and watch this one. You won't be disappointed.

This is so unfair! I really am opposed to this mean nostalgiabait, but I just could not help having tears in my eyes for those clearly set up moments of remembering the old show. It is just: After all the bad trek with its imposed crying that never ever worked, I am just prone to this bit of obvious but true feeling. 
So is Picard 3 a master of a show? No. Is it all about the nostalgia? No. As old and young actors both work great. It is that the characters are still evolving - even those of Riker and Co. And, oh, Jonathan Frakes! Why do show us your true ability of acting that late in live? 
There sure are logic plotholes. But they are not as obvious or lorebreaking that they really count (one thing that Deanna did, was not what she normally would do). 
So what is this show then? 
It is decently written, emotional through story not through a protagonist crying, it is funny, it is true to the world before, it tries to connect ... well, Generations. 
And the enemy was better hidden until now than Sauron (come on! EVERYBODY knew it was him all along!).
So here we go: It is Star Trek as it always was. Some good episodes, some not so good. Over all just good fun and tension. 
It is plain entertainment and escapism. That is much more than most of the shows lately. Writers of the world: Look at Picard 3.

For all fans of Star Trek: The Next Generation, this is the show you've been waiting for! The first two seasons of Picard were decent adventures with lovely nostalgic moments, good new characters blended with a few legacy characters, and some very satisfying moments of resolution for a few heavyweight characters, namely Data and Q.

But season 3 is basically the ultimate TNG reunion tour. It gets the whole core cast of TNG (minus Wil Wheaton so far, though he had his cameo in season 2) back together for one final thrilling adventure. Also returning is the wonderful Jeri Ryan as Seven of Nine and she again develops more depth into her character in almost every scene she gets an opportunity to perform in. Also returning is Michelle Hurd as Raffi, who continues to shine in this season, though with a slightly more back seat role this time to clear room for the legacy characters. 

And there are some new characters to get to know and explore as well, including Jack Crusher, (excellently played by Ed Speleers) the LaForge daughters, and, perhaps most notably, Captain Liam Shaw, played to near-perfection by Todd Stashwick. Shaw has quickly shifted from an irritating and obstinate obstacle for the heroes to become a fan favorite character worthy of helping his own show, should an opportunity arise. 

And I would be remiss not to include Amanda Plummer as the villainous Vadic, who very well might be the best Trek villain since the great Ricardo Montalbahn as Khan, himself. (Honorable mention to the Alice Kreig's Borg Queen) She chews up scene after scene with a perfect blend of intelligence, egomania, and chaotic madness that sits right on the edge of "over-the-top" without ever going over into campiness. In some moments, she's truly terrifying. Yet Plummer and the writers manage to make her a somewhat sympathetic character with her backstory. She's a truly fantastic and all time great Trek Villain!

And of course, the original cast… they're all back and in top form. Each character gets some worthy screen time and development that adds depth, warmth, and humor to them. It's impossible, as a fan, to overstate the joy of seeing these characters all together again for one more exciting adventure! It would be too long of a review to detail each actor's best moments, but suffice it to say, fans of each will certainly find moments to really love.

The visuals are also amazing! New ship designs by wonderful artists from both Trek past (Rick Sternbach, Doug Drexler, and Michael Okuda all return to offer input) as well as new (ship designer Bill Kraus, in particular, provides glorious new designs that are inspired by the best of past Trek) offer "starship porn" galore that really feel like a blend of classic Trek and new, exciting designs. And the sets are absolutely beautiful. Also amazing are the costumes and updated uniforms. Cosplayers will have a field day with these updated designs, certainly.

The season is packed with adventure, nostalgia, Easter eggs galore, wonderful writing, excellent visuals, and just great Trek fun. Kudos to showrunner Terry Matalas for some of the best Star Trek ever and I, for one, sincerely hope he is involved in more Trek productions to come. If so, the franchise is in excellent hands. Well done and, if this is to be Picard and TNG's swan song, it is a most worthy ride indeed. LLAP…

First off can anybody please change the Series Info for the this show! Picard is not deeply affected by the loss of Data. 
Did anybody else watch TNG? Picard tolerated Data, there was numerous episodes where Picard would show his frustrations with him, but he valued him as an important crew member. Once, they thought Data was dead and Picard's reaction was "We need a replacement officer". The only person Data was truly close to was Geordie and called him his best friend.... let me use this as a sudden transition to talk about Season 3. 
After seeing (somehow getting through) the first 2 Seasons, I honestly can not believe Data acknowledge Geordie before he did Picard (S3 E5). I know this is a oddly specific point, but for me this is Proof the writers have finally done their homework. Also note Picard now speaks like TNG Picard, short abrupt language in conversation, none of the absolute poetic drivel he was spurting out in S1 & S2. The fan service is nonsensical to the max but hey you wont care as long as the "real" bands back together, hey we have even got a very good villain who isn't a one dimensional revenge cry baby. What's more is we've got a little bit of all the shows thrown in now, the grittiness of DS9 plot, seemingly a follow up and have the Dominion just evolved or is their more to it.....maybe a team up with Species 8472...oof, sorry that's a deep cut. 
The only thing I really want is for Janeway to show up and tell Picard he's been a melt and needs to sort it out his issues. A talking down from her would really do that man some good.

Let's start with the basics: I am a french trekkie and have watched all the TV shows, except discovery (seriously the klingons.. and the unsympathetic hero). For Enterprise, I love Scott Bakula as an actor and you want to befriend the guy.. but it was difficult to see him as an actual captain. Deep Space Nine is my favorite, then TNG. Voyager was a fun (bug too long) experience and going deeper into the Borg storyline.

Ok review: Picard season 1 & 2 are ok but disappointing; obviously the show is named Picard.. so it had to be around him, but the 2 seasons were far too centered on him, his past, his regrets, to a slow drift towards death, to the extent you might just stop caring about his storyline. Yes Picard was great but you don't want him to self-congratule, right ?

BUT season 3 is the season that all true Star Trek fans have been hoping for. And I am not writing that lightly. We have had those movies trying to transform Star Trek in space opera or making it action/adventure style.. That's just not Star Trek. Star Trek is about exploration of worlds and ideas.. And trying to make us think of the society as a whole and how it can evolve. Imagine in the 80s, we were already speaking about : what if AI becomes sentient ? Does it has rights ? Would they really be superior in all ways ? The paradox of Data wanting to be human and his counterpart Lore wanting to rule over lesser evolve humans. The transfer of consciousness in machines, the ethics and problems of cloning. Etc. True Star Trek fans love the shows because they made them think and hope in possible futures.

So now that you see how I think, here is why I love Picard Season 3 and I think it's the show we have been all waiting for:

(spoiler alert)
They finally are reusing old story arcs of characters. The relation between Kimberly and Picard. The family story of Picard, being the last of his long lasting dynasty and his deep regret of not having a son. Worf and his internal human/klingon conflict and how to behave properly, mastering and freeing his inner violence when needed and being... just Worf (imagine Jadzia speaking). Riker and Troy, their family, their lost son, the effects on them and yet their everlasting love being challenged. Ro Laren and the deep intrication of the Bajoran religious (parallel to WWII, the occupation, rebellion, faith, pardon).. and even.. changelings and the dominion wars ! Possibly I have a bias here as DS9 was my favorite of all show, but it's great to see that epic storyline coming back with all that it can bring to the universe. Now, I don't know *yet* they are going with it.. and it could be that they completely fail at the end of the season, especially if they are push to finish early and they won't change opinion on having a season 4. But so far, it's been a pleasure to see that story coming up to life, and all those conflicts/fears resurfacing.

In addition to all that, they went on simple yet effective designs for the generic and for the music. Nothing too crazy, too flashy, too colorful like in Star Trek Strange New World where you feel like you may be watching a cartoon. Just the right balance to show it's Star Trek and yet more modern.. but not in the wrong way.

So what I love about that season 3 is that it's a lot more balanced: those are story lines around Picard but this time we come back to Picard and Riker living those stories rather than remembering the "good old days". And the integration of all those characters we loved definitely helped to achieve that balance and reaffirm a strong feeling of belonging to the Star Trek family.

So yes, season 3 is the show that all Star Trek fans have been waiting for, with all the characters they love, reuniting with old characters storylines, gathering them towards new adventures and the goal of saving the federation from another new infiltration of changelings.. with no one you can trust.

My only fear is this: in season 3, they are giving a lot to Star Trek fans.. and it's great. But will they be able to keep up with the pace they gave ? Will they manage to live up to all the conflicts and expectations they are raising ? I think they might.. and that the first 2 seasons they were fine tuning on how to create a Star Trek TV show in our technological/violent era where if things don't crash and burn in 2s, people are uninterested. It's not perfect, but I think they reached that level where they have a solid story, solid set of characters, solid design.. so let's go where no man has gone before !

Through Ep 5, if you were a fan of TNG and got through S1&2 of this show then you will be surprised at the quality of S3. It has not always been consistent but Ep 5 is great TV. The writing is smart in that Stewart is there and important but not the powerhouse character. Of the original cast, McFadden always seemed a bit unnecessary, and unfortunately that hasn't changed much. Michelle Hurd is a much better female lead and so far this season we have not seen enough of her. If the rumors are true about Michael Dorn, that he cant remember his lines, it makes sense that he's had some significant moments but not a lot of airtime, so far. As for Ed Speelers (Jack Krusher), still not sure what to make of him. He's fine and even though his character's story is a key plot point, it's not clear whether you should root for his success or demise.  This far into the season, that lack of clarity is probably the biggest drawback. Fortunately, the season is only halfway through, so that should be resolved soon.

Holy ****!  This is the best Star Trek that we have seen in years.  If Discovery had been this quality for its 1st season, we would have 20 Star Trek shows airing right now. I honestly feel like they could have released pairs of these episodes as theatrical movies.  When watching the first two seasons, when the episode was over I thought that it was enjoyable.  Now I am on the edge of my seat dreading the week wait for the next episode to come out.  Every episode, I have checked the time because there was soo much in it that I thought it had to be almost over.  I was pleasantly surprised when I found that there was more to come.  Does the show have some problems? Yes, however they are few in number and severity that they can be overlooked.  If you were like me and had almost given up on Star Trek, I urge you to give this season a try.  You really don't even need to watch the other seasons.  If something is discussed that seems confusing (like Picard being a synthetic lifeform) Just accept that it was something that happened in the first two seasons.
