Picard Season 3 is an exceptional addition to the Star Trek franchise, offering a unique blend of action, drama, and exploration that will delight fans old and new. From the very first episode, the show proves to be an excellent continuation of the previous two seasons, delivering a compelling storyline that captivates viewers from start to finish.

One of the most significant strengths of Picard Season 3 is the writing, which is consistently strong throughout. The character development is excellent, with Jean-Luc Picard continuing to evolve as a character, while new characters are introduced with ease and depth. The dialogue is smart, engaging, and often thought-provoking, making the show a joy to watch.

Another standout feature of Picard Season 3 is the visuals, which are simply stunning. The special effects are top-notch, and the show takes full advantage of the latest technology to create breathtaking vistas and thrilling action scenes. The attention to detail is impressive, and every shot is beautifully composed and choreographed.

Overall, Picard Season 3 is a must-watch for Star Trek fans and sci-fi enthusiasts alike. With its gripping storyline, superb writing, and stunning visuals, this latest installment in the franchise is sure to be a hit with viewers. So if you're looking for an exciting and engaging sci-fi adventure, be sure to check out Picard Season 3 – you won't be disappointed!

I have to say that season 1 and 2 were a massive let down. I mean does anyone even know what the hell season 2 was all about? Thank the stars for Terry Trek making a return in season 3 because THIS is my trek. This is the trek I grew up loving not this weird modern take in it. I mean why try and fix something that wasn't broken. Let's hope that there's more of this to follow.

What a breath of fresh air.  The writing is incredibly strong, with some memorable new characters added to the legacy cast, which are acted to perfection (looking at you, Todd Stashwick).  The soundtrack by Stephen Barton has a film-like quality and very reminiscent of Goldsmith/Horner.  My only complaint is the excessively dark lighting on the bridge, though that may be something they can resolve for the DVD/Blu-ray release.  Not a deal-breaker by any stretch, though.  Even though there are a lot of in-universe nods to what came before, the show is actively moving the franchise forward in time, in a very satisfying way that makes me almost forget about some of the recent missteps in seasons 1-2. Cannot wait for episode 5, as this one appears to be heading towards quite a finale. 

Terry Matalas hit the ball out of the park with this one.  Paramount/Secret Hideout:  Please give him the keys to showrunner future Trek shows and films!
great show. great stories
Star Trek as it was always meant to be. After spoiling the Borg with that useless character, the first two horrible seasons. And let alone the distorted Netflix version. Now it really is Star Trek.

The season is intense, great acting, storytelling, unexpected plot twists,  fun to watch, good jokes and character interplay, great editing, beautiful visual effects, often poetic and touching, forward thinking, hopeful, no hero worship, good team playing. A lot of fun, I'm often on the edge of my seat. Trekkies who hated other seasons will love season 3!  TNG just got reborn,  Dr. Beverly Crusher delivers!, Riker baby blues, Shaw reinvents Moby Dick,  Worf beheads on Wednesday and serves tea like a Budist, Vadic swirls like her Dad and the dogs of war are let loose, while Shakespeare sits in the background on a stool at the Ten Forward bar and the curtain calls for Geordi,  Data and Troi to show up.  What are you waiting for? It's amazing!
The attention to detail is impeccable. A very well crafted work of art. Plays like a fine film.

I've been a Trekkie for 40 years and Picard Season 3 is an absolute masterpiece.  Unlike the first two seasons, Picard S3 doesn't just pay lip service to past Star Trek works; this time around they are woven into the story itself in a very clever way.  The suspense, the acting, the character development...  it's all Trek at it's very best.  I predict this will go down in history of one of the great works of the franchise.  Captain Shaw needs his own show...
Ok, the first two seasons were bad.. but season 3?? absolutely great so far. The old TNG feelings were flowing in me. I hope they make more seasons like this (but I think this is the final season).

Only up to episode 4 so far, but Series 3 is equally as ‘page turning' as the previous two series. A shame it's the last series, because the entire production has been both a breath of fresh air to the franchise and equally a blast of very fond nostalgic characters.

Season 3 is easily the best Trek in ~20 years. Particularly like that while the characters all have their demons, by and large they manage to stay professional and calm under pressure. Vs the insubordinate, the-bridge-as-an-adult-creche B.S. we've tended to see of late. Terry Matalas definitely needs to produce more Trek. Bravo 👍🖖
This is the best season of Picard yet! The acting is phenomenal!
Season 3 is amazing and is back to the best of TNG. Much better than season 1 and 2. Bringing the old cast back with excellent special effects and storyline and been a big win in my opinion.

Nachdem ich soviel gutes gelesen habe über die 3 Staffel , war ich echt überrascht wie gut sie mir gefällt.
Echtes Star Trek feeling für mich...

My wife wanted to watch Picard season 3 because she likes Patrick Stewart. I was surprised because I am a die hard trekkie and she had always kind of made fun of star trek before that but we are both very much enjoying it. I even think she might want to go back and watch TNG now!
This is great, I wasn't a fan of the previous seasons as much but this last season has really turned things around and I believe is a touching send off to these characters.

The writing has taken a steep downturn this season.  Lots of silly melodrama and lame attempts at humor.  If I didn't know better I'd suspect Kathleen Kennedy had a hand in this.  What a sad way to go out.
Its the comeback of all comebacks. Well done.. I couldnt stand s1 and s2 but this is good Trek in my opinion .

I never thought I'd give Star Trek five stars again. The last ten years have been bleak for this once beloved franchise; however, finally, authentic Star Trek is back!! I'm four episodes in and have loved every single one! The first two series of Picard were garbage, but this one has taken the franchise from zero to hero. Great story, brilliant acting and casting, and more of the old TNG characters are back. I now can't wait for Fridays to come around so I can watch another episode. I might even renew my annual Amazon Prime subscription! Bravo!
After an 18 year drought... Finally. Beautifully written so far (4 eps out at this time). This should have been season 1... Night and day quality difference. Can't wait for more.

Season 3 so far is awesome , why did we had to watch the absolute PAIN that were S1 and 2 ???? Why was the writing, acting, directing, camera work etc so bad and for Season 3 is sooo sooo good with ep 4 been THE  BEST so far.

It feels like the TNG movie we never got.

I have been seriously surprised with this season so far. Seasons 1 and 2 definitely had little to no good things to say about them but Season 3 they are swinging for the fences with. Even Captain Shaw and his connection with Wolf 359 was so personable in my eyes he became a relatable character in the amount of time it took for him to relive his encounter with the Borg. Why couldn't they have done this from Season One? So far I am truly enjoying watching this final season and I truly hate that this is the end because it seems the show is only now finding its footing.
can't believe how they turned this show around... This new season is like some of the best TNG episodes i ever seen... So friggin awesome. Very glad they stepped up.

Wow, I don't know what happened but this season is more than watchable (so far), I actually find myself liking it. After the bad season 1 and the absolutely horrible season 2, I had given up all hope on ST: Picard being anything but a disaster that not only ruined the character now, but also somehow tainted TNG. Good writing, effects, acting for the most part, story and it hit you over the head with preaching every episode. I'll come back and update this review if the rest of the season bobbles the landing, but for now I'm just happy we have some semblance of a Star Trek show again. Whoever took over this season from the last two, thank you. I hope you can keep it up.
Season 3 is everything I wished Star Trek: Picard would be from the very start. Terry Matalas should replace Kurtzman immediately.
Frakes is absolutely killing it this season.  Acting, directing....he's Mr. Trek.  This is some of the best Trek since DS9 and First Contact, bar none.
So far, only episode 4 is released as of this posting, but I have never felt more respected as a fan who grew up on this series. Thank you.

This whole plot is ragebait. Its so stupid, nothing makes sense. I'm searching for tiny bits of nostalgia, but that's about it. There is absolutely no intelligence involved with the story telling. Star Trek is DEAD.
Best season of trek since the end of DS9!
Excellent Trek! Though it might very well be too little too late.
Finally Star Trek makes a return.  Lower Decks is fun, but THIS season of Picard has been Star Trek returning to form.  Watch it and bring in more Terry Trek

After two attempts, the third Season of Picard is even more than fans could have hoped for: it is the true conclusion of Star Trek, The Next Generation. All the major characters are back together, and while years have passed, the  crew chemistry is there, and it is tangible between the cast we know and the cast we are beginning (?) to know. The story is familar, a powerful new enemy is seeking to destroy The Federation and Picard et al., are there to stop them. Regardless, the acting, special effects, sighs, sounds are somehow familiar and yet new. This might be the last act for Picard and The Next Generation, but when the curtain comes down we will  have been teleported to our next mission.
After episode 4 I'm full on board with this season! And I can't wait to see what's next.

Picard season 1 and 2 are a literal literal nightmare if you are remotely interested in Star trek and good writing.

But season 3 is phenomeal so far and every Episode is a joy to watch

Lifetime ST lover. But I can't give this a gushing review. The production values are excellent. Special effects as well. It's enormously gratifying to see TNG cast members (plus Voyager torchbearer Jeri Ryan and Picard regular Michelle Hurd) back together. We are back on a starship doing battle in space. Never mind that the plot is suspiciously similar to ST2: The Wrath of Khan. 

Weak spots. Oh, dear. The cinematography is at times ridiculously choppy. Why do we need to see two characters exchange dialogue from 42 angles? It accentuates the overreacting from some major characters. Michelle Hurd seems to be on a soap opera, she's emoting so hard. Maybe some of this is due to Frakes' direction. But she deserves a pass because the writers put an atrocious piece of exposition into her mouth in the first episode. It was so shameful that I imagine she needed a drink after shooting the scene just to get the taste out. There are several more melodramatic heavy lines that are just way out of character. I'm cautiously optimistic about the plot because in epi 3, they bring in the OG boogeymen from ST: Enterprise: changelings. Hoping this improves with episode 4 and following.

It started out bad and it took some convincing for me to give it a chance, but this has got progressively batter and towards the end, this has become some of the best star trek in a long time. I would place this above every single star trek production since 2005.
There are many moments where this won out for me. Shaw was fantastic and put the idiots in their place. I was so sick of the characters in modern trek acting like undisciplined children and There were numerous points in this season that directly addressed that type of behaviour. The language was also vastly improved. They didn't use as much slang from 3 centuries ago, so it felt more believable. They talked with respect and when tech jargon was used it was vague enough and yet logical enough that it worked, rather than confusing me or making me angry. Okay there were some stinkers like "subspace frequency" which was pretty aggravating, but there wasn't much.  The lighting was improved. the ships do need more light, the crew spend a lot of time there, they need to have simulated daylight for their mental health and also to avoid eye strain, at the very least. They aren't short on power, they have a frickin warp engine.  The crew respect each other, they support each other, they don't laugh at their crewmate's misfortune or make disturbing distasteful joke. They have solidarity and professionalism. They have light humour and good natured banter. This is what I want in Star Trek. I hope they take the positive energy from this show and take this forwards. No more discovery. no more picard season 1 and 2. no more of the frat house mentality of strange new worlds. Give us more of this. 
This is Star Trek.

Ever since Star Trek Disco first aired I have felt pretty dissatisfied with the franchise. Sure there have been some watchable moments, but overall maybe with the exception of Strange New Worlds the franchise has felt like sci-fi but not Trek as we know it. I guess that the people making it and ultimately the studio did not really know what Trek was. The same was true of the Picard series UNTIL SEASON 3….

FINALLY this series IS Star Trek. It looks like Trek, it sounds like Trek, the characters are written and act like Star Trek characters. Clearly this series is made by someone who knows intuitively what Roddenberry would do and executes it well. This series is markedly different and it's just a shame it's only got good in the final series.

Make more like this CBS/Paramount…

As a a mid 20's Trekie and overall sci-fi fan I absolutely have adored Picard as a whole. 

Seeing the TNG characters written into a future plotline has been absolutely nostalgic. The whole show is a great experience even for people who aren't completely in the loop with Star Trek lore and history, it can be an enjoyable standalone experience set in the vast Star Trek universe. I'm sad that this will be the final season following Picard and friends as I've really enjoyed the newer timeline and the astonishing updated visuals. I really hope they continue down this pathway and would absolutely love to see more adventures from a young and exciting crew especially characters like Elnor. 

Afterall there's still a whole lot of unknown out there, it's time to yet again boldly go where no man has gone before. 🖖

So far, so good - but I may revise my review by the end.

But THIS feels like Star Trek. There's still a bit of woke and "The Message" being played through it, but we got some life out of Picard going on and least and the stunts they've pulled are right out of TNG's playbook.

Well done.
It's absolutely Epic. For an STNG fan it's simply the best. Indeed let's hope Paramount realise and make another series.
It's still early in the season but it looks good so far. This should have been the first season. This is what Next Gen fans were looking for.

Moves way too slowly and is dumbed down compared to the original Next Generation tv series.  All characters have changed for the worse and its dystopian mindset is opposite Roddenberrys's original idea.  Mind numbingly slow, extremely poor writing, and dialogue is similar to that of Blue's Clues.

The season isn't over in the UK yet, so there's still time to flop the landing, but so far Terry Matalas has pulled off the impossible and turned around Picard. 

Season one wasn't great but I let that go because no star trek show has ever had a great first season. But then season 2 took the plot for a decent 2 or 3 parter; and dragged it out across 10 dull, meandering, poorly written episodes, presenting characters that resembled their original characters in name only...and at that point I was done with the show.

Until I heard they were bringing back the whole TNG cast, so I forced myself to watch it just to see how badly they could ruin the show I grew up on...so imagine the surprise when they didn't!!!

So far season 3 has been a breath of fresh air. Not only do the returning characters behave in keeping with the characters they played before, but the script is tight, entertaining and well written. The visuals are excellent, the acting is well above par and every episode leaves you wanting more.

If he keeps this up, Terry Matalas can book his spot in the hallowed halls of franchise saviours, next to Filloni, Favreau and Ronald D Moore.

Give this man more star trek projects immediately!
Finally, a Picard that we can watch.  Not only no cringe, but actually movie quality writing.  I'm impressed.
Picard season 3 has brought Star Trek back to life. Thank you Paramount for giving us fans one last tribute to the crew of the Enterprise D.

This show is the opposite of engaging. 3 episodes in and I cannot care less. If you think this is comparable in any way to TNG, I'm sorry, you are stupid. I don't make the rules.

I feel bad for Shaw because he started off as a genuinely interesting character, but was quickly buried in the second episode as being completely ineffectual. Everyone acts circles around Sir Stewart, and it's all he can do to read his lines without falling asleep. Captain Riker is literally just Johnathan Frakes. And shout out to Moose and Squirrel lady who is villain of this week this time. Nailed it, guys. Completely relatable character.

The sound design...    JJ Abrahams has to be sexually aroused by the presence of the *wOOOOm* epic CGI enemy sound effect. I can't imagine any other reason its used so much. Its so outdated and embarrassing, it undercuts any seriousness or tension this goofy space nazi pirate cartoon villain brings to the table. Which is to say, none. 

So yea, in case you were wondering if the majority of the positive reviews are bots, they are. Or just someone significantly lacking in brain striations, who is easily manipulated by emotional cues. The only way I was able to make it through 3 episodes was with a friend, to make sure I stayed awake to prevent long term brain damage. Only watch if you're interested in knowing how many decapitations are in this season. Bon appetite! 

#Smoothpicard
Excellent last season, everyone liking the Star Trek universe will love season 3

I've been an avid Star Trek fan since 1966 and know this franchise well...and let me say I couldn't be more disappointed in Season 3 so far.....ridiculous, rehashed plot from Wrath of Khan (existential maniacal villan, hiding in nebula, surprise son for Star Trek Captain....).  I actually cringed at some of the ludicrous  dialogue  and subsequent lousy acting in Episode 3!!  These actors, this franchise and the fans deserve much much better.  The whole team behind this mess should be ashamed of themselves...THIS SUCKS!!!!

Finally, they found the secret sauce. Some will say it is fan service. I say, "What else should you do other than make something that people will watch. And, the base of whom you should seek to please should probably consist of the - wait for it - fans." It is filled with nostalgia but doesn't waste time relying on it. Rather, there are intricate relationships, conflict, pained emotions, and more. The visual effects are stunning; and, there is enough tension to wind you to the moon and back.

Why did they not start this way?
Three episodes in and it's already lightyears better than the last two seasons.
Really enjoyed it, unlike S1+2 or Disco.

Not only does this welcome back some classic TNG characters, it also introduces some great new ones.
New villains, a new alien race, new three-dimensional crew members, new weapons!
It's a love-letter to the fans and, in my opinion, has totally redeemed the previous two seasons of dire garbage.
Better than the first 2 but still too nihilistic. Glad they haven't cut anyone's head off this season.

Firstly, I've been watching Star Trek since ST:TOS season 1, so perhaps my thoughts on the subject a a bit biased. I'm only on episode 2 of Picard season 3 but I have loved every second of this so far and I'm not ashamed to say I've teared up a little at certain parts.  This show is a return to the hopeful Star Trek rather than the gritty dire Star Trek we come to expect from the latest shows.  The last few seasons of Discovery I've watched, just because it's Star Trek. ST:SNW I enjoyed, Picard season 1 was depressing, season 2 started well but dragged on and on and I was glad when it was over.  Picard season 3 I can't wait for each episode and am getting up early to watch.  Jean Luc has finally woken up and the band is back together.  More please.

Another failed attempt to recapture the greatness that was TNG, thanks to bad writing, and a failure to stick to canon. If the people writing this show had written TNG, it would have long faded from memory and history. The actors we KNOW have the ability to be awesome, have been undercut to the point of making them look like a terrible B-movie actors. The characters, whom any fan would be very familiar with, do not behave anything like the characters we remember. They are strangers with familiar faces, and this Season is little more than the longest and worst of Star Trek movies. Why bother recalling TNG just to spit on it? Disgrace.

Such an improvement over the previous seasons, picard season 3 is a love letter to the fans. Not only is this a faithful sequel to the next generation, it also has solid writing and direction, the plot is brilliant and is gripping edge of your seat kind of stuff which will have you screaming for more.

To say that Season 3 is a breath of fresh air it is an immense understatement.  The show feels like actual Star Trek again.  I love seeing the old crew again, the writing is so much better, and the absolutely abysmal characters Jurati and Rios are gone - hallelujah.   Those two were so freaking awful, I couldn't stand it.  Picard being a strong man again is amazing; from the first episode of this third season, when he started being himself and not cowering behind others for once, I wanted to applaud.  Loved how he was written and acted in episode 3 especially, when he had his heated discussion with Beverly.  So glad he said what he did.  There are moments that are bizarre, like in episode 3 when Riker has an emotional and, frankly, irrational outburst at the end and orders Picard off the bridge.  Also, it didn't make sense when the actual ship's Captain didn't immediately go to warp once they picked up Picard, Riker and the Crushers near the nebula; he instead wanted to hang out in non-Federation space to feed his curiosity, which was so out of character from what had been established. One other odd thing is why Raffi is treated like some amazing hero; she is (and always has been) overly dramatic and emotional in all of her reactions, although I hand it to her for her tenacity.  I see her as mediocre as a character.  Oh - and one other thing I've noticed: these show writers and visual artists are totally ripping off The Expanse.  The gritty, thumping bars where Raffi goes every episode are like Belter establishments.  I like the look, but it's a total rip off.  I just hope that the season continues the way it started; I am genuinely enjoying this season, whereas I couldn't stand Season 1 and just tolerated Season 2 (except for those powerful scenes between Q and Picard at the end - those scenes made the slog worth it).

So far, so... Okay? The writing is mediocre, while also frustratingly teasing us with true-to-character moments occasionally. Crusher vs Picard in episode 3 simultaneously showed flashes of our titular character reappearing, while also (once again) demeaning him by conveniently finding a different way to repeat the sentiment: "sheer f*(%ing hubris".

But, as in all modern trek, no one thinks or communicates in a way that is indicative of a professional Starfleet officer. It is always childish, sometimes vindictive, drama -- Riker made a statement to Picard near the end of episode 3 that you would NEVER hear from him, nor anyone else in Starfleet. The statement was wholly dramatic, not constructive, vengeful, and out of character. And would in no way serve to help their situation, and would be trained OUT of Starfleet Officers to think as a reasonable response to a mistake.

The show is watchable is because it sits next to all of the unfaithful, arrogant, modern trek, and just has to not make a mess of itself to look good. But also the chemistry of the original cast is still apparently intact, and I'll keep watching for that fact.
Pure ambrosia. Star Trek at its finest. Can't wait to see more of the characters from other Star Trek shows. So sad it's the end of the series for Picard.
Dynamic, engaging and humorous. Between Stewart and Frakes on screen friendship and Seven's continuing growth in Starfleet, this show is amazing.
Waaaaayyy to close to the movie that basically ended the franchise at the time.

Finally a realization of what was promised when Jean-Luc returned. This is not only what Star Trek fans were waiting for, but what the general audience deserves. A beloved crew, coming back together, unintentionally, to give us another thrilling ride through the stars.

Well........I really dont like the jumping between story lines in one episode.  If they are trying do it a sequence of events on a timeline ... Ok fine.   The commercial cuts are bit harsh.  This show is no "Expanse".

After the third episode of Picard Season 3 I'm just shook to the core in the best way possible as a Trek fan. I really hope that the show continues this level of quality writing. The twists and turns took us to a place I had no idea we were heading to.

It's nice to see the old faces again but the writing is still terrible. No respect for what has come before and a incessant need to make everything life or death. Character motivations and actions clearly not based in what has been built upon for 30 plus years. And the lack of original ideas or thought is both a testament and lack of talent that is the basis of this writers room.
Awesome Season. If they keep up with this crew then give them a Season 4 and More!
I liked the first two episodes. Would've given it 4 stars if I'd bothered to review it before this morning. Looks like they're going downhill though. I'll watch again next week just to be sure.
So far Season 3 (3 episodes in) is the BEST and truest Star Trek made in 18 years. This is Trek at it's BEST & I say that having not enjoyed one episode of Picard Seasons 1 & 2 !

AFTER YEARS OF CRAP, Picard Season 3 is now the Mandalorian!  Some are "complaining" cause the "lighting".  X  It just the "setting" of how this FINAL series is going to play itself out as....so far EPIC!

Is anyone else not seeing or willing to acknowledge this Elephant-Sized, Rehashed Clone of a story in the room? I mean everyone cried and moaned about JJ Abrams rehashing Star trek's certain Star Trek TOS movie, but seriously? This is damn near plot point by point mimicry. I won't go into details or "SPOILERS", which are plainly evident to see anyway by anyone with eyes. And what other fan channels are calling "easter eggs" to other ST stories and movies, are in fact not Easter eggs, but plot points actually lifted from....Will no one else at least admit that though it is great eye candy for a Trekkie (such as me) to enjoy ALmost anything Star Trek this is just OLDOLDOLD. We have in every season Data, form of Data or some whatever you want to call it role with Brent Spiner.  And god only knows why. Maybe it is in Spiner's contract agreement? Who knows, but his acting in these past 2 seasons come across flat, drained, and honestly with an air of self-importance not really earned. Self-serving. Picard and Data honestly never had that Kirk/Spock dynamic really going in TNG show. He seemed as close to him as Riker or LaForge.  Their dynamic was better in the TNG movies but if you are gonna pair characters up that had a dynamic on screen for long periods throughout show, then let's do so right now. If you go by TNG show (not movies) only: LaForge/Data, Riker/Troi, Picard/Worf (which makes hella more sense considering what Picard did for him). Or even Picard/Crusher/Crusher. No, I didn't stutter. Any decent Trekkie worth their salt knows what I am inferring. First and second season, but especially first season all but said it outright. Then came Riker's Beard. 

Not a decent season of Picard. And that is a shame. None of the new characters introduced throughout these seasons had enough backstory fleshed out for us to bond with and care about. Except the Musketeer that stayed behind last season in Earth's past. I think he is now Harry Mudd's great-great-great-great grandfather. There is a story guys, and please take my idea (but let someone other than your team write it..so call my agent) He carried his scenes, very well. Only for these guys to write him out. Guess nobody should outshine the star. Foolish. At least he had a stallion to ride on into the sunset. He wasn't a red-shirt at the end. The only other one left worth serious interest (and I was surprised to even see her at the beginning) is Orla Brady. She is downright beautiful, and I love her. They offer us a glimpse there might actually be something now between the two. NOW That is a hella way to do a nice sendoff for a legend, by pairing him with a beautiful costar. The hero (whose wife in real life btw is way, way younger than Orla...some of you just cringed-it's true) saves the universe, gets the beautiful woman, and both can ride off together into the sunset. NOPE! They bench her 15 minutes in. Which makes no sense by their own story up to that point "Trust nobody in Starfleet" -SHE ISN'T STARFLEET SHE IS TAL SH'AR!! Someone that everyone is LITERALLY SCREAMING they want more of on-screen. Orla also easily carries her scenes (look her up in Doctor Who..choice!!!) and she always shines. Can't outshine the star. Starting to see a trend forming here. Btw I have no issue with age, I applaud him. But his wife needs to leave some of that vigor in him for the show. He needs it to keep up, and it shows. especially in the fireplace scene with Orla.

But back to my original point and wrap this up (like I sincerely hope this show does) Adding insult to these past 2 lackluster seasons,  they don't even try to give it a proper sendoff in the 3rd Act(season). They weave a 1 hr separate story(which in fact steals from its own past TNG source material) into another story, a weak imitated knock-off copy of a truly wonderful TOS story that was once wonderful to watch. I literally could run these side-by-side to point out how identical, but whatevs. That would be "SPOILERS", but saying that about this is like saying don't tell someone that water is wet. Now there could be a final curveball or two, a mild surprise and fake-out, before this ends. But the fact that this season is leaning hard into that material shows weak writing and laziness to begin with.  There is nothing to spoil here. Is there no original story they could have run with at all? Or are they all being given to Discovery and New Worlds (which is so far flawless.. almost, and the night is still young, they have plenty of time to ruin it) This offering is disappointing. And quite frankly not the way to let a Legend in the franchise, one that they have propped back up only to send back out to ride into the sunset.  
Not on a beautiful white stallion..

But a donkey.

Raffi is the Jar-Jar
I'm sure Michelle Hurd is a fine human being, but her character is whiny and annoying. I wish as a fan, production would have brought back Ro Laren in her stead. That would have been AWESOME!
Everything else...Great Job!

Great intro to Warf!!  Would have been better if Raffi was killed off. Now we have to continue listening to more of her whining and crying as all the other characters are waiting around for her to finish her overacted soliloquies.

Just loved seeing the whole TNG family back again- this was all that was needed for the past 2 seasons. I only wish this was the trek presented right up from season 1. Just more brightness, please. Space may be dark but spaceships are not!

Season 1&2 just didnt work, it wasn't star trek and the story was poor for both seasons. Season 3 so far after 3 episodes has a great story and is proper star trek in a cool modern way that feels like TNG but also new. 
As a huge star trek fan, especially TNG, I couldn't get into Picard Season 1&2, but I'm loving Season 3. 
Well done, I'll want more! 
If it's can't be Picard season 4 then it will need to be Captain Worf!

This is cynical, pointless time wasting with very odd, miniature-looking CGI. 
Even my fourteen year old saw straight through it.
So far, surprisingly mediocre. Wouldn't recommend, but it's better than the last two seasons by a lot.
A massive improvement on the last 2, Shame it finally gets it together just before it ends

Grew up watching TNG and to be able to see these older characters come together again is a joy to watch. Of course without a great story it would be all a waste. Luckily the writers have done an amazing job of a fresh story and capturing the essence of what the old shows and movies brought and also introducing new faces. Love the show,  sad it's the final season.

This season has been phenomenal so far. I can't wait to see the rest of the episodes!!! Still surprised by how good this season is. It does a great job of honoring the past without being corny. It seems like Picard is just finding itself. I hope they continue to make more!!!
SNW aside, this season is the best single Trek season since Season 5 of DS9. I say this having already watched the first 6 episodes. Hopefully it ends as strong as it begins.

Finally, we get what we all wanted in Picard season 1. Season 3 so far has been great. I love having the old music and the right feel to it. It looks and feels like Star Trek that I grew up with, which was the Next Generation crew. For those complaining there's to much "Fan Service" in it. Get over yourselves! Star Trek has been around for 60 years because of the FANS. As a fan of the show my entire life, I enjoy the "Fan Service" and think we should get more of it. Why not have a show for the fans? Paramount you finally have it figured out. Don't let it end here! We need Star Trek Legacy after this in this time line.

I've only seen two episodes and I'm so ready for someone to find the light switches on these ships. Has lighting become too expensive for the federation? Also, why did Beverly never tell Picard he had a son? When the prisoner escapes the brig, why do they not just ask the ship to find this person instead of running around looking for him? And when they were told to find the prisoner, no one gave them a description, so they did not know who they were looking for. When Riker wakes Beverly up, why does he make her walk from sick bay to the bridge instead of beaming her there? They seem to have forgoten how technology works in their world. It's the little things that they used to do in TNG that they are overlooking that are annoying.
FINALLY! STAR TREK is back! It's a shame this is the final season of PICARD. Maybe if the ratings are good they will continue! Fingers Crossed!

Only two episodes in but enjoying every minute.  Yes, it's dark.  But so was TWOK.  The musical score is amazing.  It's a TV show... not every minute of Breaking Bad was great either.  But as a whole, both episodes were top notch.  Keep it up please - we need more!

So far, this season feels like I've woken up from a fever dream during seasons 1 and 2. CBS and Paramount need to hand Terry Matalas the keys to the kingdom. He knows what we want to see in Trek. The third season is a return to the Trek we know and love.
So far this is the best Star Trek.

I'd honestly lost hope after the first 2 seasons. It seemed like a vanity project set in the star trek universe. However Terry Matalas has proven not only can Star Trek still be a relevant show for the modern audience but he can lead star trek into a new era, 'the undiscovered country'.
The original cast are back with a few new faces that inspire the imagination.
Wow, star trek is truly back!

What an amazing season so far, More than just seeing the cast back together, This has all the action, story and overall quality one could hope for, this feels more like a movie than a show. If the TNG movies had this back when it was made it would have been blockbusters!

You eat at a restaurant twice, each time you come home and vomit afterwards. On the third try, you come home expecting to vomit but you don't. Then you're like holy moly, I didn't vomit. This in a nutshell is picard season 3. Fans of the classics will not vomit, even if it's not perfect. Sure, the lighting is horrible, the plot is sometimes transparent, and the music is lifted straight from the movies. But the characters seem like the characters we know. This is probably as good as trek will get for a very long time, so enjoy it while it lasts.
Finally! This is the Star Trek TNG I remember. Perhaps a bit darker and more modern, but still it got that... feeling... that I've missed for so many years. More of this please!

Borrowing the attention span of Marvel television shows, the superficial character drama of dating TV shows, and the intellectual depth of "adventure race" series, Star Trek: Picard Seasons 2 and 3 do a disservice to Star Trek. The pacing is one of the areas where, in my opinion, the show falls most importantly short of TNG (my primary comparison point, though I'm familiar with most of DS9, Voyager, TOS, and SNW); by cutting with millisecond-precision in order to dole out 1-gram morsels of plot development, the show makes no illusions about treating its viewers like screen-addicts who will wander away to another almost-identical TV show unless they are constantly tantalized. Two episodes of Picard: Season Three are enough for me. Lastly, these faults of course are not the actors', who are the shining light of this series (I'm a fan of pretty much all of them, old and new; they do an excellent job, consistently). The problems with it are squarely blamable on the relevant TV executives, who have no concept of giving viewers and the world of storytelling more than already is.

How can you not like Picard!  I end up clapping at the start and the end of every episode.   I love the respect and inclusiveness of all past cast members.  Every episode is full of easter eggs that should excite fans.  I hope they do season 4
This season is my dream come true.  The Next Generation is back and better than ever!

While the show still lacks many of the classic aspects that made the star trek franchise a monumental success - I have to admit that, so far, season three seems to have improved light years over the steaming dog crap of seasons one and two. The storyline still relies too heavily on characters with no prior connection to the main character (such as the strung out, overly dramatic false heroism of a former crack head whose been plaguing us since season one) rather than Picard himself. The female to male crew casting is still grossly disproportionate, and the majority of the acting (aside from the original next gen cast) is so overly dramatic and poorly executed, it often seems more like a low budget soap opera than Star Trek. 
HOWEVER - despite all of this, season three is what season one SHOULD have been. You have a much higher focus on the show's namesake than in the first two seasons, we are FINALLY reintroduced to some of the beloved characters from first gen. Isn't this what fans were expecting in the first place - a good old fashioned dose of nostalgia?
While there is still room for improvement, it does appear the writers are reluctantly starting to listen to the people who made this franchise the success it is : the fans.

Star trek is not only a TV Show, here for me in Brazil is the concept of a free mind and bravery that fulfill my entire life with all the good things, a light that showed to me that fight is not the only way. Picard remembered this idea and boldly go where no series has gone before, directly to the heart.
Wow!!!! This is amazing!!!! Get the word out Trek fans.
Important to support shows when they rediscover what made them good in the first place...

Don't understand the love for season 3 so far, it's just everything we've seen before but repackaged with the voice of now not that of the distant future. Seasons 1 and 2 tried to give us the new but were poorly delivered.

Two episodes in and Season 3 is already light years ahead of anything done in Seasons 1 or 2.  What's the difference?  The characters finally feel like older versions of the characters we knew from the TNG days, older more experienced but still the same characters at their core.  The dialogue for once isn't painful to listen to.  The overall writing and pacing is excellent, except for the Raffi storyline which doesn't quite mesh with the rest of the show.  Michelle Hurd is stuck in Season 1 and 2 mode.  Two episodes in and the Raffi stuff is my least liked part of the season so far, but everything else makes up for it.  It's a minor dislike as she is much more likeable this season as a character.  I know it's only two episodes in but I'm loving it so I'll give it 4 out of 5 stars so far.

Its weird that character like Raffi who was highly unstable served in star fleet and later in intelligence division. It might be a good season but so far it lacks everything apart from a reunion of dying stars.

I am especially thankful for all of the women involved in the cast.  Stellar performances from Jeri Ryan and Michelle Hurd! I never thought I would say this but I love this Star Trek. This is Star Trek.

This is the season that true TNG fans have been hoping to get for many years.  We finally see the Jean Luc from TNG and not the "modern retelling" of his character.  The subtle Easter eggs calling back to familiar TOS movies and TNG episodes are many but do not feel contrived or like pandering — they evince the careful attention to detail brought forth by a new show runner who truly knows, understands, and loves the Star Trek that I fell in love with as a child.

Episode 1 was great! Gave up on 1 and 2 pretty quickly but this looks promising.

Se3 Ep01 was a great season opener, with one major disappointment.   In an era where medicine offers tricorders, hyposprays, VISORS that cure blindness, successful de- assimilation of former Borg drones, alien telepathic and empathic therapeutic modalities, Emergency Medical Holograms, etc..., how does a Star Fleet officer end up repeatedly kicked out of Star Fleet because of addiction rather than being offered effective treatment?   One of the best things about Star Trek is that it shows us what it might be like to live in a society free (or at least significantly freer) from discrimination based on gender, race, disability, and sexual orientation.   How is it possible in such an advanced society that there have been no advances in the treatment of addiction and no lessening of addiction stigma?

Wow - They really turned the show around this season!! It's entertaining and compelling in the way that it unfolds the story over the runtime with great editing and pacing.  The characters are much more layered and nuanced in their portrayal, and the actors are at the top of their game.  The production design is much more in line with TOS, TNG and DS9. The orchestral score is so great; it's really emotionally moving!! You have to pay attention to the details in each scene, and that's not an issue because this season really does draw you in with its high quality storytelling and unexpected plot. The showrunner is doing a focused political thriller this season, and it has a Tom Clancy vibe to it.  It's really good, and I'd highly recommend it even if you didn't enjoy the first two seasons; it's basically a brand new show now like TNG S8 or STAR TREK XI.

The Best season of Star Trek in 25 Years! Showrunner Terry Matalas has created a connection to legacy Star Trek we believed would never return. We need more #TerryTrek - The entire cast is the best they have ever been. After 20 years, they still have it! Must Watch for any Star Trek fan.

Having seen episode one, I am ... unmoved. There was nothing offensively bad about this. But at the same time, it still has the same signature to what came before.

The member-berries - I don't care. You're not going to win be over with TWOK nods in the opening credits or with the low-res Titan's space dock departure (CGI isn't terrible but damn, The Expanse was way ahead of this quality years ago).

The dialogue, the interactions ... a lot of it fell flat - even between Riker and Picard. Is it nice to see them together mucking about on a derelict ship like the good ol' days? Sure. And the writers are not shy about reminding us how nostalgic this all is.

We're also setting up yet another mystery box, it would seem. They always intrigue at the outset but grow tiresome fairly quickly as they're nudged along each week. If you're going to unpack a mystery across 10 episodes, you had better give me some quality, character-driven content to fill the space between the cursory reveal episodes. Regrettably, NuTrek has yet to deliver on this front, with cliched, shoddy and inconsistent writing being the norm.

Ultimately, the NuTrek viewing experience is a frustrating one as the serialized mystery box is drip fed across several weeks. One wonders if the early reviewers' sentiment was aided by being privy to watching the whole season (or first six - whatever the case may be) back-to-back.
